# Lab 1: Digital I/O, Analog In, PWM Out

## Topics:
- Digital I/O
- Analog In
- PWM out
- USB breakout board
- Without APIs
- Microphone (solder)

## Extra Credit:
- Assembly

content.content: In this lab, you will learn the fundamentals of working with the ESP32 microcontroller. You'll explore digital input/output operations, analog input, and PWM output. You'll also work with a USB breakout board and solder a microphone component.

- Configure and use digital input/output pins
- Read analog values using the ADC
- Generate PWM signals for output control
- Interface with a USB breakout board
- Implement functionality without using high-level APIs
- Solder and interface with a microphone component
- (Extra Credit) Write assembly code for specific functionality

- ESP32 development board
- Breadboard and jumper wires
- LEDs and resistors
- Push buttons or switches
- Potentiometer
- USB breakout board
- Microphone component
- Soldering equipment

### Part 1: Digital I/O

1. Configure one pin as a digital output and connect an LED
2. Configure another pin as a digital input and connect a push button
3. Write code to toggle the LED when the button is pressed

### Part 2: Analog Input

1. Connect a potentiometer to an analog input pin
2. Read the analog value and print it to the serial monitor
3. Map the analog value to control the brightness of an LED

### Part 3: PWM Output

1. Configure a pin for PWM output
2. Generate a PWM signal with varying duty cycle
3. Use the PWM signal to control the brightness of an LED

### Part 4: USB Breakout Board

1. Connect the USB breakout board to your ESP32
2. Configure the necessary pins for communication
3. Implement a simple data transfer protocol

### Part 5: Low-Level Implementation

1. Implement at least one feature without using high-level APIs
2. Document your approach and explain the low-level operations

### Part 6: Microphone Integration

1. Solder the microphone component
2. Connect the microphone to your ESP32
3. Read audio input and process the signal
4. Implement a simple audio-responsive application

### Extra Credit: Assembly Code

1. Identify a function that could benefit from assembly optimization
2. Write assembly code to implement this function
3. Compare the performance with the C/C++ equivalent

Submit the following:

1. Your complete code with comments explaining each section
2. A circuit diagram showing all connections
3. A brief report (1-2 pages) explaining your implementation and any challenges you faced
4. A video demonstration of your working project
5. (If applicable) Your assembly code with explanations
